utterances: So long.
Let's try Charlie, Charlie's calling us from the road in Milwaukee, Wisconsin.
Hello, this is wonderful that you're doing this show.
Well, thank you.
I can't believe anybody even cares.
Me, neither.
Yeah, really.
I have been - actually, I met Richard many, many years ago.
About a thousand years, I guess.
I've been doing stand-up for about 25 years.
I'm a headliner, work all across the country, and I think it really depends on what you want out of the business.
I agree with Richard that if you're looking for the TV and all the rest of it, you got to be in New York or L.A., but I've done this for 25 years, nobody knows who I am.
I headline every club I work and I make a fairly decent living out of it.
You know, it's not all bummers.
It's not like you - it depends on what you want.
That's right.
Depends on the lifestyle you want.
Clubs, they don't want to pay the money, gas is high but you got to be willing to bust your butt.
That's really what it comes down to.
You got to make the phone calls, you got to get out there and push and you know, hope that again, like Richard's saying, I grew up at a time like he did that everybody helped each other.
And it sounds ...
I wish there was more of that in this business now.
And Charlie, it sounds like you represent yourself.
You're trying to hustle the jobs on your own.
Well, I do a lot of it myself because one thing I learned in this business is nobody cares whether you're working as much as you do.
I also have a part-time manager that used to be my full-time manager but if he wasn't going to work, then that means I got to go out and do it.
I understand.

It's a pain but it's part of the business and anybody - unless you're a lot higher up on the rung than I ever got, you know, you do a lot of it yourself and it's not - you know, I live in a nice house.
I've been married for 24 years.
I have a good life.
Wow.
That's a really - he made a really...
Five years...
Charlie, hold on.
Go ahead, Richard, I'm sorry.
No, I apologize.
What he said was so articulate and so on the money.
Look, life's a short journey, you know, and the truth is he's doing very well and he's a success.
And someone might say, I'm not a success unless I win an Emmy or an Oscar.
That's their right, but you know, there's a lot of people who don't have to have, you know, don't have to headline, have HBO specials and consider themselves failures if they don't.
You know, he's a successful, you know, actor for 25 years, lives a great life, has an ongoing marriage and that's more than 99 percent of the world.
So, you know, that's the problem with a lot of people in the business.
It's just people think that you have to have, you know, you have to live on top of, you know, have 300 bedrooms to be a success.
And that's just not where it's at.
So this comedian, you know, he has the right attitude.
Esther, would you be willing to right now sign up for Charlie's career?
Yeah, I would!
I mean, my goal in comedy is to make my sole living, make my - you know, make bread come out of comedy full time.
So that would be amazing, if I could do that.
Right.
All right.
Charlie...
Well, good luck, Esther.
Thank you!
All right.
Esther, we hear horror stories about life on the road.
And well, a lot of what Richard writes about in his memoirs is about his alcoholism and learning to deal with it and that.
But life on the road is tough.
It's tough on marriages, it's tough on people's lives.
Are you ready for that?
Yeah, you know, it's weird for me being so young and like seeing how many comedians have come before me, and a lot of them were drug addicts and alcoholics.
And I don't know if that makes you a better comedian or if I should stay away from it or delve into it.
Because, you know, there are so many great comedians who were, you know, living that lifestyle.
I don't know, you know, it's like what caused what, you know?
Yeah.
What comes first, the chicken or the egg, Richard Lewis?
No, I got to tell you something.
You know, I've been sober a long time.
Most of the people I know who are recovered drug addicts and alcoholics are not in show business.

It's just - it's a tremendous - there's more enabling going on if you're in show business than say, you work for a plumbing supply company, because they want you to go do your show even if you're falling down drunk so they can get their percentage, their commission.
But that's more than, you know, maybe it'll be a nice owner of a catering firm will say, hey, listen, you're not going to put this Bar Mitzvah on.
We're going to send you to a doctor.
But I mean, listen.
It's an enabling business.
You're around liquor and booze all the time.
But you know, you can wake up every morning and say, how do I want to live my life, regardless if you're in show business or whether you're an engineer.
We're talking with Richard Lewis and Esther Ku, both comedians, about the business of comedy.
You're listening to Talk of the Nation from NPR News.
And Tim is on the line, Tim's on the road in South Carolina.
Hi, how are you doing tonight?
All right.
Tim, you're on the road as a comedian or you're on the road - are you a hit man?
I am on the road as a comic.
I actually liked hearing Charlie speak.
He was inspiring.
Yeah.
But I'm in the same boat of working.
I'm just up to headline.
I'm working every weekend that I want, meaning about three weekends a month.
I'm on my way right now down to Florida.
And that's another thing, traveling from North Carolina to Florida for a gig, ten hours, one way.
By the time we get done doing, I don't how Charlie is doing it.
I'm booking all the gigs.
Three years ago I was all right.
Right now, I'm thinking about walking away from the only thing I've ever loved this much, you know?
It's the traveling and all that stuff, it's - you know, when you get on stage, that's the easy part.
It's getting there and it's getting on that - hearing your name is the fun part and hearing the laughs.
But boy, I don't care how high or low you are on the scale of, you know, name, of notoriety.
It's still a bitch to travel, no matter what you do, unless, of course, you know, you're so well off you have private planes and all that crap.
But I mean - not crap, if you're lucky enough to have that, fine, but man, he's right.
Remember that French tennis player who was 25, won three French Opens?
She quit at 25 and then Martina Navratilova said, why don't you just take a break, you know, because she couldn't believe that she quit after all this success.
But the bottom line is you can take a break, pal, and think about it and come back in a year without making a big decision like that and putting so much pressure on yourself.
That's true.
Yeah.
And Tim, you're heading down to Florida this weekend and appearing at a club one night only, or a couple of nights?
Yeah, I'll be there, actually, Friday and Saturday.
Jokeboy's(ph) in Ocala, Florida.
All right.
I wanted to let you get the chance to get the plug in there.
Good luck to you, Tim.
Thank you guys very much.
Yeah, have a good - break a leg, man.
And you talked a little bit earlier, Richard Lewis, about George Carlin.

He died earlier this week, of course, and that's one of the reasons we wanted to do this program, because he made it possible for a lot of pioneers in the business and helped a lot of people get into the business.
And as you think about his humor - we just have a couple of minutes left, but as you think about his humor, what do you think made him so special?
Well, he was one of the great wordsmiths who ever lived.
He was one of the most, if not the most prolific comedian that ever lived.
He had an amazing work ethic.
He was unbelievably edgy, and the one thing that I find astonishing, because you know, he was 71.
When he was in his 20s and 30s he was like an - he did great but commercial bits, in a sense.
I mean, you know, Hippy Dippy Weatherman.
He made a transformation, you know.
Forget the drugs and all that stuff.
He made a transformation into, like, following along the lines of Lenny Bruce and Richard Prior.
And to make that kind of change in his style as comedian, I can't think of anybody, really.
I mean, it's almost like, and I don't mean to say this disrespectfully, Carrot Top, you know, became Brando, you know?
I mean, that's almost how much of a change Carlin did in his own persona, which to me was astonishing.
And no one really used the English language as well as he did on stage.
He was clearly a genius.
Richard Lewis, thanks very much for being with us today.
We appreciate your time.
